prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Impact of tag-along actions on proceedings in the transferee court

para.paratext: Neither the possibility of transfer of tag-along actions nor transfer itself has any direct effect on those proceedings. As always, the Panel does not suggest to the transferee court how the transferred cases, including the newly transferred cases, should be handled.[1] The extent of coordination or consolidation of the pretrial proceedings is a matter to be determined solely by the transferee court.

A practical problem is usually presented by transfer of tag-along actions, however. Although the solution of this problem is left to the discretion of the transferee court, the Panel is concerned that transfer not impose unmanageable burdens on the transferee court. Those concerns are addressed throughout this chapter.

The tag-along action may be in radically different procedural posture than the actions that were previously transferred. The knowledge of Panel proceedings relating to potential tag-along actions may cause the transferee court to consider staying proceedings until the tag-along action can be included. These matters are not taken up by the Panel, but the Panel may be aware of them.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
The Panel's deference to the transferee court is discussed in Chapter 9.
